Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Towards Sustainable Carbon-Negative Chemical Manufacturing by Creating Synergy between Carbon Dioxide Utilization and Biorefinery

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of economically viable techniques for manufacturing carbon-negative fuels and commodity chemicals from atmospheric carbon dioxide and renewable energy is a grand challenge with important societal and environmental sustainability implications. This research project explores the synergy between carbon dioxide utilization and biorefining operations for producing a particular class of chemicals, formates. Carbon dioxide is released from biorefining operations, so this "biogenic" carbon dioxide is being explored as a feedstock. The research project project aims to systematically explore and model the process chemistry of integrated carbon dioxide capture and conversion into formates. In addition to disseminating the results of this research to a broader audience via publications and presentations, the researchers will recruit undergraduate from the Pacific Northwest Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program (PNW LSAMP). The mission of LSAMP is to increase pathways to college for underrepresented minorities. The research group also commits to offering two summer internships for community college students to do research associated with this project.

The main objective of this research project is to investigate the reactivity of carbonate ions, formed by capturing carbon dioxide with amines or ammonia in aqueous ethanol solutions, for the production of formates by catalytic hydrogenation. The research project focuses on studying the process chemistry and reaction mechanism of the integrated carbon dioxide capture and hydrogenation process, in which ethyl carbonate ions are the key intermediates for the highly selective production of formates in amine-bioethanol-water solvents at near ambient temperatures. The mechanism of the formation of ethyl carbonate ions during the carbon dioxide capture process is being elucidated through theoretical and experimental studies. The structure-activity relationship of carbon supported palladium nano-catalysts is being explored using advanced experimental tools, such as in-situ nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. In particular, the influence of the surface facets of palladium nanocrystals on the activation of biocarbonate and ethyl carbonate adsorbates in the carbon dioxide-amine-ethanol-water systems is being studied. By creating synergy between value-added carbon utilization and biorefining processes, this research approach may lead to the development of new technologies for manufacturing carbon-negative chemicals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Climate Change” is a formidable challenge facing our human society in the 21st century, which is linked to the anthropic release of an overwhelming amount of CO2, a greenhouse gas (GHG), into the atmosphere by combusting fossil fuels. To achieve the target of limiting average temperature rise to 2°C in 2100 which is proposed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), policy for “negative carbon emissions” should be initiated and the research and development innovation should be invested. Bioenergy with carbon capture and storage, in particular, is considered as the most practical approach of “negative carbon emissions” in the near term. Alternatively, utilization of CO2 captured from biorefineries as a feedstock for the production of commodity chemicals offers a direct way to monetizing CO2. By creating the synergy between biorefinery and CO2 capture and utilization, “carbon-negative” commodity chemical manufacturing processes may be realized.

Herein, this NSF funded project has demonstrated the synergy between CO2 capture utilization and biorefinery for producing “carbon-negative” formate chemicals using biogenic CO2 released from biorefineries. Such synergy could not only realize zero carbon emission in a biorefinery but also improve the carbon atom efficiency of biorefining processes.  Our team has developed a novel, highly efficient formate chemical production process by hydrogenating biogenic CO2 captured by amine in bioethanol solvent over a carbon supported palladium nano-catalyst at near ambient temperatures. Leveraging the CO2 capture infrastructure to produce value-added formate and its derived commodity chemicals could improve the process economics substantially. The team has also explored a novel catalytic reaction system that is presented by coupling the dehydrogenation of glucose with the hydrogenation of a CO2 derived salt, ammonium carbonate, in the ethanol-water solutions. For the first time, the hydrogenation of CO2 into formate by glucose has been achieved under ambient conditions. Finally, the team has developed a highly efficient formate based hydrogen storage system since hydrogen carriers would have a large market in future. This system has shown rapid reaction kinetics of both the hydrogenation of piperidine captured CO2 and the dehydrogenation of formate-piperidine-adduct over the carbon-supported palladium nano-catalyst under mild operating conditions. Moreover, the formate-piperidine-adduct solution as the hydrogen storage system is advantageous owing to the generation of high-purity hydrogen, which is free of carbon monoxide and ammonia.

The postdoctoral research associate has been the primary investigator of this project, who gained not only the research experience but also the experience on mentoring the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) undergraduates. Four undergraduate students participated the project, among whom one African American student was recruited from the Pacific Northwest Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program, and another underrepresented student is a female.  All the REU students gained valuable working experience on solving practical engineering problems, and were stimulated to study in the chemical engineering program. Two REU students made the poster presentation at the WSU Showcase for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activities. One REU summer intern was selected nationally to travel to Madrid, Spain, as a “student-professional correspondent” representing the American Chemical Society at the United Nations Climate Action Summit. He will go to the United Kingdom’s University of Sheffield as Washington State University’s first recipient of a Marshall Scholarship for graduate study.
